title.narrative: Food Assistance for Assets to strengthen resilience in IPC Phase 5 locations and support to Logistics Cluster

description.narrative:
WFP has plans to scale up the Food Assistance for Assets (FFA) programme in Aweil South and Greater Tonj, where there have been significant gains made in the past 2-3 years to increase household food production, improve post-harvest practices and (re) build community infrastructure. WFP is also expanding the FFA programme geographically to include Akobo and Pibor with a view to supporting pastoral livelihood development and enhance agricultural productivity – areas which have primarily been supported by humanitarian agencies’ emergency programmes. Through this scale-up, WFP plans to reach approximately 27,000 more beneficiaries in 2021 than last year in the six counties, for a total of 95,349 affected people (15,890 households) targeted for support through FFA. These efforts will be complemented by general food distributions (GFD) (from other funding sources)to ensure the most vulnerable and labour constrained households have access to food during the hunger season. Through FFA WFP will support 15,890 households to create assets over the course of six months which will have immediate impacts on food security and enhance households’ resilience capacities.
In areas with high levels of inter-/intra-communal conflict, WFP will make intentional efforts to use FFA as a means to reduce community violence by providing livelihood development opportunities that may reduce the likelihood of populations to resort to violence.
WFP’s FFA response will be coordinated with FAO’s main season response through which the same households supported through FFA will receive agricultural inputs from FAO. WFP will provide six months of food assistance (either in-kind or cash based transfers) which will serve as a protective ration which, when timed with seed distribution, will ensure that households are able to plant the seeds instead of selling or consuming them when their food stocks have been depleted. The food assistance will also ensure that households have enough food to eat to meet the energy requirements for cultivation and the time to participate in expanded agricultural activities instead of resorting to negative coping strategies to help meet household food needs.
